College of Energy Engineering, Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China A three-site SCR model including Z2Cu, ZCuOH and Brönsted acid sites has been developed for accurately describing SCR reactions and N2O formation over Cu-SSZ-13. The N2O formation mechanism proposed by recent works was adopted. Low-temperature N2O formation is attributed to NH4NO3 decomposition on ZCuOH and Brönsted acid sites with different NH4NO3 formation routes. High-temperature N2O formation is derived from NO x -assisted NH3 oxidation on different sites with different routes. NH3 storage, NH3 oxidation, NO oxidation, Standard SCR, Fast SCR, NO2 SCR, NH4NO3 formation and decomposition were included. The NH4NO3 inhibition on low-temperature NH3-SCR reactions and N2O formation due to its deposition on catalyst surface were considered. The model has been validated by different steady-state and transient experiments. The results indicate the model can accurately predict SCR reactions, as well as N2O formation under different conditions. The model can improve NO x and N2O cooperative emission control performance in diesel engine after-treatment system. The SCR is a key technique widely used in diesel engine after-treatment systems to reduce NO x emissions [1]. NH3 is produced from aqueous urea solution and will react with NO x on SCR catalyst to convert NO x into harmless N2 and H2O in the SCR system. The SCR system performance mainly depends on catalyst activity and stability. Among several SCR catalysts, Cu-SSZ-13 has attracted much attention for its great activity over a wide range of temperatures and good hydrothermal stability, but it has severe N2O emissions compared to Fe-SSZ-13 [2,3]. N2O is a strong greenhouse gas whose greenhouse effect is 298 times the equivalent of CO2, and many regulations (China Ⅶ, Euro Ⅶ, etc.) have considered limiting its emissions in the future [4]. Understanding of N2O formation mechanism and developing an SCR kinetic model including N2O formation over Cu-SSZ-13 is beneficial for N2O control in the diesel engine after-treatment systems. Many studies about N2O formation mechanism over Cu-SSZ-13 have been conducted. N2O shows bimodal formation under Standard SCR and Fast SCR conditions indicating that N2O formation at low and high temperatures has different reaction routes [5]. Many studies suggested that low-temperature N2O formation is associated with NH4NO3 [6–9]. For example, Chen et al. [10] reported that N2O formation comes from NH4NO3 decomposition, an intermediate that forms on the catalyst from the reaction between NH3 and surface nitrate groups under the existence of NO2. Zhu et al. [9] reported that the formation of N2O is associated primarily with the reaction of NO x with proton-adsorbed NH3 via the formation and subsequent thermal decomposition of NH4NO3. At high temperatures, N2O formation comes from NH3 oxidation [11]. Zhang et al. [12] reported that NH3 nonselective oxidation is the main reaction of high-temperature N2O formation, and the reaction route follows the Eley-Rideal mechanism. In addition, N2O will decompose at high temperatures. Lin et al. [3] proposed that N2O decomposition follows a dual-site mechanism. There are different active sites over Cu-SSZ-13 that may be in charge of N2O formation. Liu et al. [13] proposed that NO3 - from NO2 disproportionation will react with NH3 on Brönsted acid site to form NH4NO3 under Fast SCR conditions. Shan et al. [14] suggested that NH4NO3 can form on both ZCuOH and Brönsted acid sites, and the latter is mainly responsible for the NH4NO3 formation. A comprehensive SCR kinetic model is very important for NO x control in diesel engine after-treatment systems. Many models have been established to capture the SCR catalyst dynamics. Olsson et al. [15] developed a three-site SCR model including Z2Cu, ZCuOH and physisorbed site, and Brönsted acid site was lumped together in the Z2Cu and ZCuOH sites for simplicity, the NH3 adsorption/desorption, Standard SCR, and NH3 oxidation were considered in the model. But the reactions involved NO2 which have a significant contribution to N2O formation were not considered. Li et al. [16] built a one-site NH3-SCR model including N2O formation from NH3 oxidation over commercial Cu-zeolite catalyst based on AVL BOOST, while the NH4NO3 formation and decomposition were ignored. Bendrich et al. [17] developed a dual sites SCR reaction model that one site accounts for the adsorbed NH3 that forms on the Brönsted acid sites and copper ions, and the other one is cooper ion (ZCuOH) where nitrites and nitrates are adsorbed, but the high-temperature N2O formation due to unselective Standard SCR to N2O was not modeled. Gao et al. [18] developed a two-site detail kinetic model including the NH4NO3 formation and decomposition where S1 site is mainly Cu and Brönsted acid sites and S2 site is physisorbed sites, as well as some copper and Brönsted acid sites. And Selleri et al. [19] developed a reduced one-site NH3-SCR automotive converters model including a fully detailed kinetic scheme accounting for the most important features of the NH3-SCR reactivity. However, the NH4NO3 decomposition into N2O was ignored in their models. Daya et al. [20] developed a two-site detailed global kinetic model including N2O formation on both sites where S1 site is ZCuOH and Brönsted acid sites, and S2 site is Z2Cu and physisorbed sites, besides, they considered the NH4NO3 storage in the model which leads to the NH4NO3 inhibition on low-temperature SCR reactions. However, they did not model the NH4NO3 formation under Standard SCR conditions, which leads to low-temperature N2O formation in the Standard SCR process. Although many SCR models have been developed, precise N2O formation prediction is still hard to obtain. Precise SCR model including N2O dynamic is important for diesel NO x emission control, especially for greenhouse gas N2O and NO x cooperative control. In general, studies about the N2O formation mechanism over Cu-SSZ-13 have been conducted widely [5,8,10–12,21–23]. However, the N2O formation at a wide temperature range was not considered comprehensively in published SCR models, including low-temperature N2O formation derived from NH4NO3 decomposition and high-temperature N2O formation derived from NO x -assisted NH3 oxidation on different active sites [14,23–25]. Therefore, in this work, a kinetic SCR model has been established with N2O formation, N2O decomposition and NH4NO3 inhibition over Cu-SSZ-13. Three active sites including Z2Cu (S1), ZCuOH (S2), Brönsted acid (S3) sites were considered. NH3 storage, NH3-SCR, NH4NO3 formation and decomposition, N2O formation and decomposition were modeled here to capture the catalyst behavior. Moreover, NH3-SCR reactions will be inhibited at low temperatures. The NH4NO3 will deposit on the active sites and prevent reactants from contacting active sites and inhibit NH4NO3 self-decomposition. The inhibition terms were included in the model to improve model accuracy at low temperatures. The model parameter estimations and validations were carried out based on different flow reactor experiments. The developed model here can be used for the model-based control systems to improve NO x and N2O emission control performance in diesel engine after-treatment systems. 2 Modeling 2.1 N2O formation mechanism Several experimental observations indicated that N2O formation over Cu-SSZ-13 displays bimodal features under Standard SCR and Fast SCR conditions [5]. Low-temperature N2O formation comes from NH4NO3 decomposition [7,18]. However, low-temperature NH4NO3 formation over Cu-SSZ-13 has different routes on different sites [8]. Cu-SSZ-13 has multiple types of active sites that have different contributions to low-temperature N2O formation. Under Standard SCR conditions, NH4NO3 will only occur on ZCuOH site [8,26], but under Fast SCR conditions, NH4NO3 will form on both ZCuOH site and Brönsted acid site [8,13]. Hence, in order to accurately reflect Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst SCR reaction characteristics and N2O formation characteristics, three active sites were adopted here including Z2Cu site (S1) located in 6-membered ring windows, ZCuOH site (S2) located in CHA cages and next to 8-membered rings and Brönsted acid site (S3) located in the zeolite [27]. NH4NO3 formation and decomposition into N2O reactions at low temperatures are given by [15,18]: (R1) 2 S 2 − N H 3 + 2 NO + O 2 → S 2 − N H 4 N O 3 + N 2 + H 2 O + S 2 (R2) 2 S 2 − N H 3 + 2 N O 2 → S 2 − N H 4 N O 3 + N 2 + H 2 O + S 2 (R3) 2 S 3 − N H 3 + 2 N O 2 → S 3 − N H 4 N O 3 + N 2 + H 2 O + S 3 (R4) S 2 − N H 4 N O 3 → N 2 O + 2 H 2 O + S 2 (R5) S 3 − N H 4 N O 3 → N 2 O + 2 H 2 O + S 3 High-temperature N2O formation is different from low-temperature N2O formation. Since NH4NO3 has been almost consumed completely and hardly exists over 350 °C, high-temperature N2O formation can only derive from NH3 oxidation or NO x -assisted NH3 oxidation [12]. According to recent works [5,9], high-temperature N2O formation has two routes including NO-assisted NH3 oxidation on ZCuOH site and NO2-assisted NH3 oxidation on both ZCuOH and Brönsted acid sites over Cu-SSZ-13 under SCR conditions. Since N2O formation is lower than 1 ppm under NH3 oxidation conditions, the NH3 oxidation into N2O reaction was not modeled. Hence, high-temperature N2O formation reactions are given by [12,21]: (R6) 4 S 2 − N H 3 + 4 NO + 3 O 2 → 4 N 2 O + 6 H 2 O + 4 S 2 (R7) 6 S 2 − N H 3 + 8 N O 2 → 7 N 2 O + 9 H 2 O + 6 S 2 (R8) 6 S 3 − N H 3 + 8 N O 2 → 7 N 2 O + 9 H 2 O + 6 S 3 In addition, N2O self-decomposition will occur at high temperatures [3]. This reaction was modeled in the gas phase in the SCR model in order to accurately describe N2O behavior at high temperatures [28]. The reaction is given by: (R9) 2 N 2 O → 2 N 2 + O 2 2.2 SCR mechanism The SCR reactions between NH3 and NO x over Cu-SSZ-13 follow the Eley-Rideal mechanism where NH3 is first adsorbed on the catalyst surface and then reacts with NO x [29]. As stated in Section 2.1, three active sites with nonactivated NH3 adsorption were adopted in the model. The proportion of Z2Cu and ZCuOH measured by H2-TPR is approximately 0.32, while the NH3 storage capacity ratio of Z2Cu and ZCuOH measured by NH3-TPD is approximately 0.65 [30]. The characteristic results are in consistent with the conclusion that reported in the literature that each Z2Cu site can adsorb approximately two NH3 molecules, and each ZCuOH site can adsorb approximately one NH3 molecule [30–32]. Since the multiple adsorbed NH3 molecules on same active site have similar activity [33], one adsorbed NH3 molecule per active site was modeled in our model for simplicity, while the total NH3 storage capacities of different active site were remain unchanged. Three reversible NH3 adsorption and desorption reactions on different sites are considered: (R10) N H 3 + S 1 ↔ S 1 − N H 3 (R11) N H 3 + S 2 ↔ S 2 − N H 3 (R12) N H 3 + S 3 ↔ S 3 − N H 3 NH3 oxidation is significant in the SCR process at high temperatures. Many works suggested that NH3 oxidation only occurs on copper sites [34]. Furthermore, ZCuOH site has more oxidation ability, and NH3 adsorbed on ZCuOH will not only be oxidized into N2, but also be oxidized into NO [20,35,36]. The NH3 oxidation reactions on S1 and S2 are given by: (R13) 4 S 1 − N H 3 + 3 O 2 → 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O + 4 S 1 (R14) 4 S 2 − N H 3 + 3 O 2 → 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O + 4 S 2 (R15) 4 S 2 − N H 3 + 5 O 2 → 4 NO + 6 H 2 O + 4 S 2 The NO oxidation reaction is very important for SCR behavior at high temperatures. The reversible NO oxidation to NO2 was modeled and the reaction rate was set proportional to the active site density on S2 [20,37]. And the reaction is given by: (R16) 2 NO + O 2 ↔ 2 N O 2 The Standard SCR is the main reaction taking place on copper sites, and Brönsted acid site has no contribution to Standard SCR activity. The Standard SCR reactions are considered: (R17) 4 S 1 − N H 3 + 4 NO + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O + 4 S 1 (R18) 4 S 2 − N H 3 + 4 NO + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O + 4 S 2 In the presence of NO2, Fast SCR and NO2 SCR will occur on Cu-SSZ-13. Many studies suggested that Fast SCR involves nitrite and nitrate formation and decomposition, but the exact mechanism of Fast SCR has not been confirmed yet [29,38,39]. To describe N2O formation and Fast SCR simultaneously, the Fast SCR occurring on the S1 site was considered a global reaction, and the Fast SCR occurring on the S2 site was considered as the combination of NH4NO3 formation and reaction between NH4NO3 and NO which is vital for N2O formation. The reactions are given by: (R19) 2 S 1 − N H 3 + NO + N O 2 → 2 N 2 + 3 H 2 O + 2 S 1 (R20) S 2 − N H 4 N O 3 + NO → N 2 + N O 2 + 2 H 2 O + S 2 (R21) S 3 − N H 4 N O 3 + NO → N 2 + N O 2 + 2 H 2 O + S 3 The NO2 SCR is another SCR reaction involving NO2, and it only occurs on the S1 site and S2 site. The NO2 SCR reactions are given by: (R22) 8 S 1 − N H 3 + 6 N O 2 → 7 N 2 + 12 H 2 O + 8 S 1 (R23) 8 S 2 − N H 3 + 6 N O 2 → 7 N 2 + 12 H 2 O + 8 S 2 Furthermore, recent experimental observations [40] indicated that NH4NO3 could decompose into NO2, and those reactions are given by [18]: (R24) 4 S 2 − N H 4 N O 3 → 4 S 2 − N H 3 + 4 N O 2 + O 2 + 2 H 2 O (R25) 4 S 3 − N H 4 N O 3 → 4 S 3 − N H 3 + 4 N O 2 + O 2 + 2 H 2 O NH4NO3 deposition will inhibit low-temperature SCR reactions [41]. The NH4NO3 deposition prevents reactants from contacting active sites. Besides, NH4NO3 deposition will inhibit its self-decomposition because of restricted mobility in the CHA tunnel [20,40]. The recent experimental results indicated that Fast SCR reaction rate will increase with NO2/NO x increase in the range of 0–0.5, while the NO x conversion doesn’t increase as expected [40]. This unexpected NO x conversion decrease caused by NH4NO3 inhibition was modeled. NH4NO3 inhibition terms were introduced here to account for this phenomenon. The inhibition terms are summarized in Table 4. 2.3 Reactor model A SCR model was developed by using one channel model with 10 grid points in axial direction [15]. The tested monolith samples were drilled off from a full-size commercial catalyst monolith. The sample properties were characterized by ICP, SEM and H2-TPR. H2-TPR experiment was carried out on a Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 chemisorption analyzer. The sample was pretreated in 10% O2/N2 atmosphere at 500 °C for 1 h and then cooling down to 50 °C. The sample was heated subsequently from 50 °C to 1000 °C with the temperature ramp of 10 °C/min in the 10% H2/Ar at a flow rate of 50 mL/min. The detail properties of sample are shown in Table 1. Prior to flow reaction experiments, each sample was degreened in a flow of 350 ppm NO, 350 ppm NH3, 10% O2, 7% H2O and N2 as balance gas at 600 °C for 4 h. The degreened samples were pretreated with 10% O2, 7% H2O and N2 as balance gas at 600 °C for 1 h and then cooled to ambient temperature in the same atmosphere before each experiment. All the experiments were conducted in a flow reactor, the catalyst sample was put in a quartz tube and the reaction temperature was controlled by the furnace. The type K was placed downstream of the catalyst sample to monitor catalyst temperature. The MKS Multigas 6030D Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectrometer was used to monitor the upstream and downstream gas concentrations of the catalyst sample. The flow reactor experiments for model development including steady-state experiments and temperature programmed desorption (TPD) were conducted. All the experiments had 10% O2, 7% H2O and N2 as balance gas in the feed gas. 60,000/hour gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was adopted in these experiments. The steady-state experiments were conducted from 150 °C to 500 °C, while N2O direct decomposition experiment was conducted from 150 °C to 550 °C to capture more obvious N2O direct decomposition characteristics. The NH3-TPD experiment was conducted with NH3 adsorption at 150 °C and then purged for 30 min in 7% H2O and N2 atmosphere. Thereafter, temperature programmed desorption was performed with a temperature ramp from 150 °C to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The detail of steady-state flow reactor experiments for model parameter estimations and validations are summarized in Table 2. Another transient experiment is introduced to further validate the SCR model and the detail of the experiment is stated in Section 4.3. All the reaction rates described in the SCR model were using the Arrhenius equation listed in Table 3, where A i is the pre-exponential factor, E i is the apparent activation energy, R is the gas constant, T is the temperature, θ NH3-i is the NH3 coverages of different three NH3 storage sites (S1, S2 and S3), θ AN-i is the NH4NO3 coverages of different two NH4NO3 storage sites (S2 and S3). The model parameters were fitted to the steady-state experiments and TPD experiment. The experiments used for calibrating specific model parameters are listed in Table 2. The calibrated parameters are listed in Tables 3 and 4. The initial values of model parameters are adapted from references [18,45]; Ω1, Ω2 and Ω3 represent the NH3 storage capacities of active sites where Ω1 = 11 mol/m3, Ω2 = 17 mol/m3, Ω3 = 34 mol/m3, and the initial values of Ω1, Ω2, Ω3 are calculated by the method reported in the literature [46]. Keq is the equilibrium constant of NO oxidation which is adapted from reference [18]. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Model calibration 4.1.1 NH3 storage calibration Fig. 1 shows the comparison of measured and simulated NH3 concentration in the NH3-TPD experiment. The simulated NH3 concentration is consistent with experimental data during all the processes, especially for the steady-state and temperature program desorption process. As shown in Fig. 1(B), the measured NH3 concentration display obvious two desorption peaks at around 280 °C and 400 °C during the temperature program desorption process. The desorption peak at around 280 °C is assigned to the desorption from Lewis acid site, and the desorption peak at around 400 °C is assigned to the desorption from Brönsted acid site [30]. Since the apparent desorption activation energies of Z2Cu and ZCuOH are similar, the simulated low-temperature desorption peak from Z2Cu and ZCuOH sites are highly overlapping and cannot be divided into two obvious peaks. The calibrated apparent desorption activation energies of Z2Cu and ZCuOH are lower than that of Brönsted acid which is corresponded well with the experimental data and DTF computed results reported in the literature (120–151 kJ/mol) [15,47]. The introduction of H2O storage or physically adsorbed NH3 storage in the SCR model may further improve model prediction accuracy [15,18,32,48–50]. 4.1.2 NO, NH3 oxidation and N2O decomposition calibration The results from the experiment and simulation under NH3 oxidation conditions are compared in Fig. 2(A). The reaction rate of NH3 oxidation into N2 increases with temperature rise beyond 200 °C with the activation barrier in the range of 70–195 kJ/mol [15,18]. At higher temperatures, adsorbed NH3 will be further oxidized into NO with higher activation barrier, which is in the range of 180–200 kJ/mol as some literature reported [45,51]. The calibrated apparent activation energy of NH3 oxidation into N2 on Z2Cu and ZCuOH sites are similar while the calibrated apparent activation energy of NH3 oxidation into NO on ZCuOH site is much higher. This result is consistent with the results reported in the literature [15,18,45,51]. In general, the model captures NH3 oxidation trend well. NO will be oxidized into NO2 under NO oxidation conditions, which is important in the high-temperature SCR process over Cu-SSZ-13 [52]. Fig. 2(B) shows the measured and simulated NO and NO2 concentrations. As the temperature increases, the NO concentration decreases and the NO2 concentration increases concomitantly. The calibrated apparent activation energy of NO oxidation is consistent with experimental results (35–70 kJ/mol) reported in the literature [53,54]. The model prediction is also consistent with the NO oxidation experimental data. Fig. 2(C) shows the comparison of experimental and simulated results under N2O decomposition conditions. The N2O will decompose into N2 at high temperatures. The calibrated apparent activation energy of N2O decomposition is slightly higher than the value (113 ± 4 kJ/mol) reported in the literature [3]. The simulated results show that the calibrated model can predict N2O decomposition well. The comparisons of transient simulated and measured results shown in Fig. S1 could further demonstrate the validity of model transient performance. In general, the model can predict catalyst oxidation and N2O decomposition performance well and it helps describe the SCR features and high-temperature N2O formation accurately. 4.1.3 NH3-SCR calibration Fig. 3 shows the comparison of the experimental and simulated steady-state results under Standard SCR conditions. As shown in Fig. 3(A), the NH3 concentration decreases with the temperature rise and is close to zero ppm at high temperatures. While the NO x concentration first decreases with the temperature rise from 150 °C to 325 °C and it increases at higher temperatures due to NH3 oxidation. The model is able to capture the trend well whereas the steady-state maximum error of NO x concentration and NH3 concentration are 19.2 and 10.9 ppm. The comparison of the experimental and simulated transient results shown in Fig. S2 further demonstrates the validity of the model. As some literature reported, the apparent activation energies of Standard SCR reactions are in the range of 80–140 kJ/mol, and they are influenced by Cu/Al ratio, state of Cu ion and reaction temperature [55,56]. The calibrated model parameters are reasonable and in the range of approximately 80–110 kJ/mol, close to the values that many other SCR models adopted [15,18,28,45]. Fig. 3(B) compares the measured N2O formation with the simulated results. There is a peak of N2O formation at around 225 °C with the value of approximately 10 ppm. The N2O concentration decreases from 225 °C to 350 °C because the reaction between NH4NO3 and NO accelerates [57]. At higher temperatures, the N2O concentration rises again due to the NO x -assisted NH3 oxidation. The simulated N2O formation rates from different pathway shown in Fig. S4 is consistent with the N2O formation mechanism adopted here. The N2O formation from NH4NO3 decomposition first increase with temperature increase and then decrease, while N2O formation from NO x -assisted NH3 oxidation increase with temperature rise. The present model is able to reflect the N2O formation characteristic under Standard SCR conditions with the maximum error of 0.6 ppm. Fig. 4 compares the experimental data and simulated results under the conditions of NO2 existence. As shown in Fig. 4(A), NO x and NH3 concentrations have a similar trend compared to that under Standard SCR conditions, while NO x and NH3 concentrations are lower at low temperatures due to the Fast SCR reaction. The comparison of the experimental and simulated transient results shown in Fig. S3 further demonstrates the validity of the model. The current model is also able to capture the SCR reaction characteristic under Fast SCR conditions with the maximum discrepancy of 23.5 ppm for NO x concentration and 15.0 ppm for NH3 concentration. The calibrated apparent activation energies are higher than that of Standard SCR reactions and litter lower than the experimental data (approximately160kJ/mol) and DFT results (below 150 kJ/mol) as literature reported [7,58]. Since the reactions between NH4NO3 and NO are the rate-limiting step for Fast SCR reactions, the apparent activation energies of NH4NO3 and NO reactions are similar to Fast SCR reactions [26]. Fig. 4(B) shows the experimental and simulated N2O formation. The N2O formation displays a similar profile with a higher peak value compared to that under Standard SCR conditions at low temperatures. The additional N2O formation is due to more NH4NO3 formation under Fast SCR conditions. The simulated N2O formation rates from different pathway shown in Fig. S5 is consistent with these experimental results. The developed model can describe this phenomenon reasonably with the maximum error of 1.2 ppm. 4.2 SCR steady-state validation 4.2.1 Model validation with the different ANR The developed SCR model was further validated by the experiment with the ANR of 1.2 under Fast SCR conditions, which is different from conditions for model calibration. Fig. 5 shows the measured and simulated results. As shown in Fig. 5(A), compared to the conditions with ANR of 1, the outlet NO x concentration decreases at high temperatures, while NH3 concentration will not close to zero ppm at midterm temperatures thus NH3 slip happens. The more NH3 in feed gas will not affect the low-temperature NO x conversion since many active sites are covered by NH4NO3. However, extra NH3 will reduce NO x emissions at high temperatures. The present model can describe the NO x and NH3 dynamic well with the maximum error of 23.5 ppm for NO x concentration and 22.9 ppm for NH3 concentration. As shown in Fig. 5(B), the N2O formation under the conditions with higher ANR is consistent with N2O formation under the conditions with ANR of 1. These results indicated that more NH3 in feed gas will not affect the N2O formation. The present model is able to describe the N2O formation characteristic well with the maximum error of 2.1 ppm. In general, the developed model can predict the SCR process well with accurate N2O formation prediction under conditions with different ANR. 4.2.2 Model validation with the different NO2/NO x The developed SCR model was further validated by the experiment with NO2/NO x of 0.2 under Fast SCR conditions. Fig. 6 shows the comparison of measured and simulated results under the conditions with NO2/NO x of 0.2. As shown in Fig. 6(A), the outlet NH3 and NO x concentrations at low temperatures are lower than that under the conditions with NO2/NO x of 0.5, since Fast SCR reaction proportion increases under higher NO2/NO x conditions. And the unexpected concentration rise is due to the NH4NO3 inhibition effect [59–61]. This phenomenon also supports the necessity of considering the NH4NO3 inhibition effect in the SCR model. The developed model is able to describe the NO x and NH3 reaction characteristics well with the maximum error of 11.3 ppm for NO x concentration and 6.9 ppm for NH3 concentration. Fig. 6(B) shows the N2O formation under this condition. The results indicate that a higher NO2 proportion in NO x will lead to more N2O formation at both low and high temperatures. The discrepancy between experiment and simulation is lower than 1.3 ppm. The developed model captures the N2O formation well under conditions with different NO2/NO x . 4.2.3 Model validation with the different space velocity The developed SCR model was further validated by the experiment with a different space velocity under Fast SCR conditions. Fig. 7 shows the measured and simulated data under the conditions with a space velocity of 40,000/hour. In slower space velocity, reactants will stay on the catalyst surface longer and thus can react more fully [62], the NH3 and NO x concentrations at low temperatures are obviously lower than that under the conditions with higher space velocity. The model describes the NO x and NH3 behavior well in the wide temperature range. The maximum error of NO x concentration is 17.7 ppm and the maximum error of NH3 concentration is 13.4 ppm. Fig. 7(B) shows the measured and simulated N2O formation. The results show that N2O formation has a similar bimodal profile under conditions with a different space velocity. The developed model is able to capture the N2O formation from 150 °C to 500 °C with the maximum error of 3.0 ppm. In general, the developed model can capture the SCR and N2O formation performance well. 4.3 SCR transient validation The developed SCR model was further validated by the transient experiment at 300 °C with a space velocity of 60,000/hour. The inlet concentrations of NH3, NO, NO2 and O2 are shown in Fig. 8(A) and the results of measured and simulated outlet gas concentrations are shown in Fig. 8(B)–(D). At the beginning of the NH3 adsorption step, NH3 concentration increases and reaches a steady state. At the NH3 oxidation step, NH3 concentration decreases once O2 occurs, and then reaches a steady state. For SCR steps including Standard and Fast SCR with different ANR and NO2/NO x , the outlet NH3 concentration gradually decreases closing to zero ppm because of the great activity of Cu-SSZ-13. And the outlet N2O increases due to the decomposition of accumulated NH4NO3. The N2O concentration varies with ANR and NO2/NO x change, and NO2 will lead to more N2O formation. The simulated results of NH3 coverage and NH4NO3 coverage are shown in Fig. 8(E)-(F). The NH3 coverage of Brönsted acid site is higher than the NH3 coverage of Z2Cu and ZCuOH sites at the temperature of 300 °C. As much literature reported, Brönsted acid site is the NH3 storage site where NH3 is stored at high temperatures. The NH4NO3 coverage is close to zero at 300 °C, while the NH4NO3 coverage of ZCuOH is higher than that of Brönsted acid site. The simulated results are consistent with the reaction mechanism adopted in the model. The NH4NO3 will deposit and decompose into N2O at low temperatures. With the temperature rise, the reaction between NH4NO3 and NO will consume the accumulated NH4NO3 and lead to N2O formation decrease at around 250–350 °C. Totally, the developed SCR model can capture the catalyst behavior well under transient conditions. 5 Conclusions In this study, based on the N2O formation mechanism over Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts in previous works, a multi-site SCR model of Cu-SSZ-13 including N2O formation and decomposition mechanism was established to predict N2O formation during NH3-SCR process over Cu-SSZ-13 under different conditions. To accurately describe the SCR reaction and N2O formation process, three kinds of NH3 storage sites including Z2Cu (S1), ZCuOH (S2) and Brönsted acid (S3) were adopted in the model. The Z2Cu and ZCuOH have main NH3-SCR activity and NH3 oxidation activity. The low-temperature N2O formation mainly occurs on ZCuOH and Brönsted acid sites under Fast SCR conditions, while N2O formation only occurs on ZCuOH site under Standard SCR conditions. At high temperatures, NO2-assisted NH3 oxidation reactions occur on both ZCuOH and Brönsted acid sites, while NO-assisted NH3 oxidation reaction only occurs on ZCuOH site. Besides, the impact of NH4NO3 on low-temperature SCR activity and N2O formation was also considered. The results show that the model predicted steady-state NH3-SCR performance and N2O formation with reasonable accuracy. coredata.dc:description: A three-site SCR model including Z2Cu, ZCuOH and Brönsted acid sites has been developed for accurately describing SCR reactions and N2O formation over Cu-SSZ-13. The N2O formation mechanism proposed by recent works was adopted. Low-temperature N2O formation is attributed to NH4NO3 decomposition on ZCuOH and Brönsted acid sites with different NH4NO3 formation routes. High-temperature N2O formation is derived from NO x -assisted NH3 oxidation on different sites with different routes. NH3 storage, NH3 oxidation, NO oxidation, Standard SCR, Fast SCR, NO2 SCR, NH4NO3 formation and decomposition were included. The NH4NO3 inhibition on low-temperature NH3-SCR reactions and N2O formation due to its deposition on catalyst surface were considered. The model has been validated by different steady-state and transient experiments. The results indicate the model can accurately predict SCR reactions, as well as N2O formation under different conditions. The model can improve NO x and N2O cooperative emission control performance in diesel engine after-treatment system.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanism-based kinetic modeling of N2O formation on SCR activity over Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts for diesel vehicle
